article.title: Variability Properties of 4 Million Sources in the $TESS$ Input Catalog Observed with the Kilodegree Extremely Little Telescope Survey

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the solid black line in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The median rms for light curves observed in the W orientation.
The median rms for light curves observed in the E orientation.
The expected precision based on a noise model, assuming a specific airmass and sky background.
The difference in rms between the E and W orientations.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the blue dot in the top left panel of Figure 3 represent?
choices: The average rms value for all stars in the field.
The rms value of a specific variable star in the W orientation.
The rms value of a specific constant star in the W orientation.
The cut-off value above which a star is considered variable based on the rms metric.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why are periods between 0.5 and 0.505 days and 0.97â€“1.04 days masked in the top row histograms of Figure 5?
choices: These periods are likely to be aliases of the lunar cycle.
These periods are likely to be aliases of the calendar year.
These periods are likely to be aliases of the sidereal and solar day.
These periods are too short to be considered astrophysically relevant.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from Figure 7 regarding the amplitude of variability for stars identified through different methods?
choices: Stars identified through variability metrics tend to have smaller amplitudes than those identified through periodicity requirements.
Stars identified through variability metrics tend to have larger amplitudes than those identified through periodicity requirements.
The amplitude of variability is similar for stars identified through both methods.
The figure does not provide information about the amplitude of variability.
